Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 11:34AM AlohaGirl wrote: I haven't had radiation yet so can't speak from experience but my surgeon did tell me to wait at least 6 months after finishing rads before having a mammogram because of scar tissue from the radiation and that there could be scar tissue present even after that, so I bet that is what it is.  Hopefully some of the other women will have more helpful information.  Hang in there!  I'm sorry you are having to go through this stress.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2010 05:29PM AlohaGirl wrote: I burned some, but it was manageable and not until a couple of weeks in.  I think it varies from person to person though.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: questions about radiation icey Chicago1018

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 05:45PM AlohaGirl wrote: Dawn, I had a wire inserted for my lumpectomy.  They told me that they couldn't use painkillers (perhaps because I had the lumpectomy under general anaesthesia).  I found the tight compression from the mammogram more painful than the actual insertion of the wire.  The procedure hurt, but the folks in radiology used an ice pack to numb the skin a little and their supportive demeanors made the experience OK.  For me it wasn't too bad.  Definitely a tolerable level of pain.  I think once you get below the skin there aren't a lot of nerves (I don't know that for a fact, that is just my theory).  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: wire guided excisional biopsy dm1991 cleomoon

Posts.Content: AlohaGirl wrote: So, I had some bloodwork done recently and everything was normal except that my highly sensitive C reactive protein (hs-CRP) levels were high (normal is below 1 and mine were 7.5).   My doctor thought perhaps this was from the radiation (I finished in June) and we are testing again in a couple of months.  She thought it was unusual that this would be so high with nothing else looking problematic.  (Of course it could be that I had a minor infection of some kind when I had my bloodwork done, or maybe it is genetic or something -- my grandfather did have heart disease when he was fairly young and apparently high levels are linked to future heart disease.)  I don't think I've had this tested before (at least not that I know of).  I was wondering if anyone else has had a similar result.  Thanks! Dx 2/18/2009, DCIS, Stage 0, Grade 3, 0/0 nodes Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: hs-CRP Levels AlohaGirl AlohaGirl

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2009 04:01PM AlohaGirl wrote: It doesn't say on it what model it is but it looks like the number on it is 79984.  It isn't super supportive, but is really soft and comfortable and definitely more support than a men's t-shirt.  You may be OK in sports bras, too.  I wore some throughout my rads, but you are right it is hard to find ones that you don't have to pull over (if your skin gets burned that will hurt).  I did find some though.  One was the "fiona" bra by moving comfort which is tigher and more supportive than the soma bra (I wear them running).  That worked well for me too but sometimes I wanted something less restrictive, esp since my armpit was swelling sometimes too (still does some of the time unfortunately but it is getting better).  I also got a champion bra (don't know its name but it is style 1697) that I liked though sometimes the hard bits along the side bothered me when I was swollen/skin was tender.  I got that one from Title 9 Sports online but I don't see it there anymore. I hope this helps.  I definitely recommend you try the Soma one!  Fiona is great too in terms of support but it definitely compresses things more which wasn't always comfortable for me (but was great when I was more active).
Posts.Title: Wearing undershirt instead of bra: but need support linn56 desdemona222b

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2009 12:00PM AlohaGirl wrote: I actually wore a bra throughout rads, though my skin did pretty well.  Not an underwire, though.  I either wore a looser fitting sports bra or a different non-underwire bra.  I'm large breasted so I would definitely be uncomfortable without a bra, and after surgery, my lumpectomy breast was also very sore if it bounced around (still is a little bit but not bad).  My favorites were some bras my sister got me at a store called Soma.  They look like a sports bra but are softer and less supportive.  I still wear them sometimes!  After surgery I wore them even to sleep because my nipple was so sensitive it drove me crazy (that is better now though occasionally there are twinges), and after I recovered from that I wore them through rads because they gave me some support without binding or poking.  I love them!  I still wear them when I'm hanging around the house!  I'd definitely recommend those.  I looked on the web site and I'm pretty sure the ones I have are the same as the Spa Kahala Leisure Bra ($30) but I'm not 100% sure.  Good luck!  I hope rads goes smoothly for you!
Posts.Title: Wearing undershirt instead of bra: but need support linn56 desdemona222b

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2010 11:01AM AlohaGirl wrote: I haven't had exactly the same experience but I did notice that the muscle under my breast area and extending to the sternum was tender after rads on the irradiated side, and also that the muscle in my armpit was very tight for a while.  Neither was a huge deal in my case but both were noticeable, especially when working out.  All is back to normal now though (I finished rads just over a year ago).  Hope this helps.  Hang in there!
Posts.Title: Pain in chest and trapezius muscles cowgal cowgal

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 12:50PM AlohaGirl wrote: I'm not sure when my soreness went away, it was gradual and one day I realized it was gone (and might have been gone for a while without me knowing).  It was a few months but it improved over that time.  The tightness also improved.  At first I had the same problem as linkert12 with extending my arm flat but I kept stretching and trying and it is definitely fine now.  Sending good thoughts your way!

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 08:27PM AlohaGirl wrote: I finished radiation in late June (after a lumpectomy in April).  My radiated breast is definitely smaller, but that could be from the lumpectomy as they took quite a bit out (shape is great though).  I would say the non-radiated breast is between a D and DD and the radiated one is a D, so not a huge difference.  My husband says he can't tell the difference.  The doctors had told me it would be about a year before I would be able to tell for certain how everything was going to look, so I'm not worrying about it now (plus I think I'm the only one who can tell, so not a huge deal).
